member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.CipherMode
member.summary: Specifies the block cipher mode to use for encryption.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.CipherMode.CBC
member.summary: The Cipher Block Chaining () mode introduces feedback. Before each plain text block is encrypted, it is combined with the cipher text of the previous block by a bitwise exclusive OR operation. This ensures that even if the plain text contains many identical blocks, they will each encrypt to a different cipher text block. The initialization vector is combined with the first plain text block by a bitwise exclusive OR operation before the block is encrypted. If a single bit of the cipher text block is mangled, the corresponding plain text block will also be mangled. In addition, a bit in the subsequent block, in the same position as the original mangled bit, will be mangled.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.CipherMode.CFB
member.summary: The Cipher Feedback () mode processes small increments of plain text into cipher text, instead of processing an entire block at a time. This mode uses a shift register that is one block in length and is divided into sections. For example, if the block size is 8 bytes, with one byte processed at a time, the shift register is divided into eight sections. If a bit in the cipher text is mangled, one plain text bit is mangled and the shift register is corrupted. This results in the next several plain text increments being mangled until the bad bit is shifted out of the shift register. The default feedback size can vary by algorithm, but is typically either 8 bits or the number of bits of the block size. You can alter the number of feedback bits by using the property. Algorithms that support CFB use this property to set the feedback.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.CipherMode.CTS
member.summary: The Cipher Text Stealing () mode handles any length of plain text and produces cipher text whose length matches the plain text length. This mode behaves like the mode for all but the last two blocks of the plain text.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.CipherMode.ECB
member.summary: The Electronic Codebook () mode encrypts each block individually. Any blocks of plain text that are identical and in the same message, or that are in a different message encrypted with the same key, will be transformed into identical cipher text blocks. Important: This mode is not recommended because it opens the door for multiple security exploits. If the plain text to be encrypted contains substantial repetition, it is feasible for the cipher text to be broken one block at a time. It is also possible to use block analysis to determine the encryption key. Also, an active adversary can substitute and exchange individual blocks without detection, which allows blocks to be saved and inserted into the stream at other points without detection.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.CipherMode.OFB
member.summary: The Output Feedback () mode processes small increments of plain text into cipher text instead of processing an entire block at a time. This mode is similar to ; the only difference between the two modes is the way that the shift register is filled. If a bit in the cipher text is mangled, the corresponding bit of plain text will be mangled. However, if there are extra or missing bits from the cipher text, the plain text will be mangled from that point on.

member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve
member.summary: Represents an elliptic curve.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.A
member.summary: The first coefficient for an explicit curve. A for short Weierstrass, Montgomery, and Twisted Edwards curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.B
member.summary: The second coefficient for an explicit curve. B for short Weierstrass and d for Twisted Edwards curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Cofactor
member.summary: The cofactor of the curve.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.CurveType
member.summary: Identifies the composition of the object.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.G
member.summary: The generator, or base point, for operations on the curve.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Hash
member.summary: The name of the hash algorithm which was used to generate the curve coefficients ( and ) from the under the ANSI X9.62 generation algorithm. Applies only to explicit curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Order
member.summary: The order of the curve. Applies only to explicit curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Polynomial
member.summary: The curve polynomial. Applies only to characteristic 2 curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Prime
member.summary: The prime specifying the base field. Applies only to prime curves.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Seed
member.summary: The seed value for coefficient generation under the ANSI X9.62 generation algorithm. Applies only to explicit curves.

member.summary: Creates a named curve using the specified friendly name of the identifier.
member.param: The friendly name of the identifier.
member.exception: is .
member.returns: An object representing the named curve.

member.summary: Creates a named curve using the specified object.
member.param: The object identifier to use.
member.returns: An object representing the named curve.

member.name: M:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.CreateFromValue(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a named curve using the specified dotted-decimal representation of the identifier.
member.param: The dotted number of the identifier.
member.exception: is .
member.returns: An object representing the named curve.

member.name: M:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Validate
member.summary: Validates the integrity of the current curve. Throws a exception if the structure is not valid.
member.exception: The curve parameters are not valid for the current curve type.

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.IsCharacteristic2
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the curve type indicates an explicit characteristic 2 curve.
member.returns: if the curve is an explicit characteristic 2 curve; if the curve is a named characteristic 2, prime, or implicit curve.

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.IsExplicit
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the curve type indicates an explicit curve (either prime or characteristic 2).
member.returns: if the curve is an explicit curve (either prime or characteristic 2); if the curve is a named or implicit curve.

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.IsNamed
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the curve type indicates a named curve.
member.returns: if the curve is a named curve; if the curve is an implicit or an explicit curve (either prime or characteristic 2).

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.IsPrime
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the curve type indicates an explicit prime curve.
member.returns: if the curve is an explicit prime curve; if the curve is a named prime, characteristic 2 or implicit curves.

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.Oid
member.summary: Gets the identifier of a named curve.
member.returns: The identifier of a named curve.

member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.ECCurveType
member.summary: Indicates how to interpret the data contained in an object.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.ECCurveType.Characteristic2
member.summary: The curve parameters represent a characteristic 2 curve.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.ECCurveType.Implicit
member.summary: No curve data is interpreted. The caller is assumed to know what the curve is.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.ECCurveType.Named
member.summary: The curve parameters represent a named curve.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.ECCurveType.PrimeMontgomery
member.summary: The curve parameters represent a prime curve with the formula B*y^2 = x^3 + A*x^2 + x.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.ECCurveType.PrimeShortWeierstrass
member.summary: The curve parameters represent a prime curve with the formula y^2 = x^3 + A*x + B in the prime field P.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECCurve.ECCurveType.PrimeTwistedEdwards
member.summary: The curve parameters represent a prime curve with the formula A*x^2 + y^2 = 1 + B*x^2*y^2 in the prime field P.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECDiffieHellmanKeyDerivationFunction.Hash
member.summary: A hash algorithm is used to generate key material. The property specifies the name of the algorithm to use. If the algorithm name is not specified, is used as the default algorithm. You can also specify the and properties, but they are not required. The amount of key material that is generated is equivalent to the size of the hash value for the specified algorithm.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECDiffieHellmanKeyDerivationFunction.Hmac
member.summary: A Hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) algorithm is used to generate key material. The property specifies the key to use. Either this property must be set or the property must be set to ; otherwise, a is thrown when you use . If both properties are set, the secret agreement is used as the HMAC key. You can also specify the and properties, but they are not required. The amount of key material that is generated is equivalent to the size of the HMAC value.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.ECDiffieHellmanKeyDerivationFunction.Tls
member.summary: The Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol is used to generate key material. The and properties must be set; otherwise, a is thrown when you use . This value generates 160 bits of key material.

is less than 1.

The pseudorandom key that is at least as long as the output byte array of the specified hash algorithm (usually the output from the Extract step).
The length of the output keying material.

is less than 1.
member.returns: The output keying material.

System.Security.Cryptography.HMAC

HMACMD5

HMACRIPEMD160

HMACSHA1

HMACSHA256
System.Security.Cryptography.HMACSHA256
HMACSHA384
System.Security.Cryptography.HMACSHA384
HMACSHA512
System.Security.Cryptography.HMACSHA512
MACTripleDES
System.Security.Cryptography.MACTripleDES
member.returns: A new instance of the specified HMAC implementation.

member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain could not be built.

member.summary: Specifies that the certificate is explicitly distrusted.

member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain is invalid because a certificate has excluded a name constraint.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.HasNotDefinedNameConstraint
member.summary: Specifies that the certificate has an undefined name constraint.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.HasNotPermittedNameConstraint
member.summary: Specifies that the certificate has an impermissible name constraint.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.HasNotSupportedCriticalExtension
member.summary: Specifies that the certificate does not support a critical extension.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.HasNotSupportedNameConstraint
member.summary: Specifies that the certificate does not have a supported name constraint or has a name constraint that is unsupported.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.HasWeakSignature
member.summary: Specifies that the certificate has not been strong signed. Typically, this indicates that the MD2 or MD5 hashing algorithms were used to create a hash of the certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.InvalidBasicConstraints
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain is invalid due to invalid basic constraints.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.InvalidExtension
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain is invalid due to an invalid extension.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.InvalidNameConstraints
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain is invalid due to invalid name constraints.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.InvalidPolicyConstraints
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain is invalid due to invalid policy constraints.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.NoError
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain has no errors.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.NoIssuanceChainPolicy
member.summary: Specifies that there is no certificate policy extension in the certificate. This error would occur if a group policy has specified that all certificates must have a certificate policy.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.NotSignatureValid
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain is invalid due to an invalid certificate signature.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.NotTimeNested
member.summary: Deprecated. Specifies that the CA (certificate authority) certificate and the issued certificate have validity periods that are not nested. For example, the CA cert can be valid from January 1 to December 1 and the issued certificate from January 2 to December 2, which would mean the validity periods are not nested.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.NotTimeValid
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain is not valid due to an invalid time value, such as a value that indicates an expired certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.NotValidForUsage
member.summary: Specifies that the key usage is not valid.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.OfflineRevocation
member.summary: Specifies that the online certificate revocation list (CRL) the X509 chain relies on is currently offline.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.PartialChain
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain could not be built up to the root certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.RevocationStatusUnknown
member.summary: Specifies that it is not possible to determine whether the certificate has been revoked. This can be due to the certificate revocation list (CRL) being offline or unavailable.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.Revoked
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain is invalid due to a revoked certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ChainStatusFlags.UntrustedRoot
member.summary: Specifies that the X509 chain is invalid due to an untrusted root certificate.

member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType
member.summary: Specifies the type of value the method searches for.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByApplicationPolicy
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string representing either the application policy friendly name or the object identifier (OID, or ) of the certificate. For example, "Encrypting File System" or "1.3.6.1.4.1.311.10.3.4" can be used. For an application that will be localized, the OID value must be used, because the friendly name is localized.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByCertificatePolicy
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string representing either the friendly name or the object identifier (OID, or ) of the certificate policy. The best practice is to use the OID, such as "1.3.6.1.4.1.311.10.3.4". For an application that will be localized, the OID must be used, because the friendly name is localized.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByExtension
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string describing the extension to find. The object identifier (OID) is most commonly used to direct the method to search for all certificates that have an extension matching that OID value.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByIssuerDistinguishedName
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string representing the issuer distinguished name of the certificate. This is a more specific search than that provided by the enumeration value. Using the value, the method performs a case-insensitive string comparison for the entire distinguished name. Searching by issuer name is a less precise search.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByIssuerName
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string representing the issuer name of the certificate. This is a less specific search than that provided by the enumeration value. Using the value, the method performs a case-insensitive string comparison using the supplied value. For example, if you pass "MyCA" to the method, it will find all certificates with the issuer name containing that string, regardless of other issuer values.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByKeyUsage
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be either a string representing the key usage or an integer representing a bit mask containing all the requested key usages. For the string value, only one key usage at a time can be specified, but the method can be used in a cascading sequence to get the intersection of the requested usages. For example, the parameter can be set to "KeyEncipherment" or an integer (0x30 indicates "KeyEncipherment" and "DataEncipherment"). Values of the enumeration can also be used.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindBySerialNumber
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string that represents the serial number of the certificate as displayed by the certificate dialog box, but without the spaces, or as returned by the method.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindBySubjectDistinguishedName
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string representing the subject distinguished name of the certificate. This is a more specific search than that provided by the enumeration value. Using the value, the method performs a case-insensitive string comparison for the entire distinguished name. Searching by subject name is a less precise search.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindBySubjectKeyIdentifier
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string representing the subject key identifier in hexadecimal, such as "F3E815D45E83B8477B9284113C64EF208E897112", as displayed in the UI.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindBySubjectName
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string representing the subject name of the certificate. This is a less specific search than that provided by the enumeration value. Using the value, the method performs a case-insensitive string comparison using the supplied value. For example, if you pass "MyCert" to the method, it will find all certificates with the subject name containing that string, regardless of other subject values. Searching by distinguished name is a more precise search.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByTemplateName
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string representing the template name of the certificate, such as "ClientAuth". A template name is an X509 version 3 extension that specifies the uses of the certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByThumbprint
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a string representing the thumbprint of the certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByTimeExpired
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a value in local time. For example, you can find all the certificates that will be valid until the end of the year by eliminating the results of a operation for of the last day of the year from the results of a operation for .

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByTimeNotYetValid
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a value in local time. The value does not have to be in the future. For example, you can use to find certificates that became valid in the current year by taking the intersection of the results of a operation for for the last day of last year with the results of a operation for of .

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509FindType.FindByTimeValid
member.summary: The parameter for the method must be a value in local time. You can use to find all the currently valid certificates.

member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509IncludeOption
member.summary: Specifies how much of the X.509 certificate chain should be included in the X.509 data.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509IncludeOption.EndCertOnly
member.summary: Only the end certificate is included in the X.509 chain information.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509IncludeOption.ExcludeRoot
member.summary: The entire X.509 chain is included except for the root certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509IncludeOption.None
member.summary: No X.509 chain information is included.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509IncludeOption.WholeChain
member.summary: The entire X.509 chain is included.

member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509KeyStorageFlags
member.summary: Defines where and how to import the private key of an X.509 certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509KeyStorageFlags.DefaultKeySet
member.summary: The default key set is used. The user key set is usually the default.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509KeyStorageFlags.EphemeralKeySet
member.summary: The key associated with a PFX file is created in memory and not persisted on disk when importing a certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509KeyStorageFlags.Exportable
member.summary: Imported keys are marked as exportable.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509KeyStorageFlags.MachineKeySet
member.summary: Private keys are stored in the local computer store rather than the current user store.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509KeyStorageFlags.PersistKeySet
member.summary: The key associated with a PFX file is persisted when importing a certificate.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509KeyStorageFlags.UserKeySet
member.summary: Private keys are stored in the current user store rather than the local computer store. This occurs even if the certificate specifies that the keys should go in the local computer store.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509KeyStorageFlags.UserProtected
member.summary: Notify the user through a dialog box or other method that the key is accessed. The Cryptographic Service Provider (CSP) in use defines the precise behavior.

member.summary: No revocation check is performed on the certificate.

member.summary: A revocation check is made using a cached certificate revocation list (CRL).

member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason
member.summary: Specifies the reason a certificate was revoked.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.AACompromise
member.summary: It is known, or suspected, that aspects of the Attribute Authority (AA) validated in the attribute certificate have been compromised.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.AffiliationChanged
member.summary: The subject's name, or other validated information in the certificate, has changed without anything being compromised.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.CACompromise
member.summary: The private key, or another validated portion of a Certificate Authority (CA) certificate, is suspected to have been compromised.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.CertificateHold
member.summary: The certificate is temporarily suspended, and may either return to service or become permanently revoked in the future.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.CessationOfOperation
member.summary: The certificate is no longer needed, but nothing is suspected to be compromised.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.KeyCompromise
member.summary: The private key, or another validated portion of an end-entity certificate, is suspected to have been compromised.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.PrivilegeWithdrawn
member.summary: A privilege contained within the certificate has been withdrawn.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.RemoveFromCrl
member.summary: The certificate was revoked with on a base Certificate Revocation List (CRL) and is being returned to service on a delta CRL.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.Superseded
member.summary: The certificate has been superseded, but without anything being compromised.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.Unspecified
member.summary: Revocation occurred for a reason that has no more specific value.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509RevocationReason.WeakAlgorithmOrKey
member.summary: The certificate key uses a weak cryptographic algorithm, or the key is too short, or the key was generated in an unsafe manner.

member.returns: A string, encoded in hexadecimal format, that represents the subject key identifier (SKI).

member.name: P:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509SubjectKeyIdentifierExtension.SubjectKeyIdentifierBytes
member.summary: Gets a value whose contents represent the subject key identifier (SKI) for a certificate.
member.returns: The subject key identifier (SKI) for a certificate.

member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509SubjectKeyIdentifierHashAlgorithm
member.summary: Defines the type of hash algorithm to use with the class.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509SubjectKeyIdentifierHashAlgorithm.CapiSha1
member.summary: The subject key identifier (SKI) is composed of a 160-bit SHA-1 hash of the encoded public key (including the tag, length, and number of unused bits).

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509SubjectKeyIdentifierHashAlgorithm.Sha1
member.summary: The SKI is composed of the 160-bit SHA-1 hash of the value of the public key (excluding the tag, length, and number of unused bits).

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509SubjectKeyIdentifierHashAlgorithm.ShortSha1
member.summary: The SKI is composed of a four-bit type field with the value 0100, followed by the least significant 60 bits of the SHA-1 hash of the value of the public key (excluding the tag, length, and number of unused bit string bits)

member.name: T:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags
member.summary: Specifies conditions under which verification of certificates in the X509 chain should be conducted.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.AllFlags
member.summary: All flags pertaining to verification are included.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.AllowUnknownCertificateAuthority
member.summary: Ignore that the chain cannot be verified due to an unknown certificate authority (CA) or partial chains.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreCertificateAuthorityRevocationUnknown
member.summary: Ignore that the certificate authority revocation is unknown when determining certificate verification.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreCtlNotTimeValid
member.summary: Ignore that the certificate trust list (CTL) is not valid, for reasons such as the CTL has expired, when determining certificate verification.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreCtlSignerRevocationUnknown
member.summary: Ignore that the certificate trust list (CTL) signer revocation is unknown when determining certificate verification.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreEndRevocationUnknown
member.summary: Ignore that the end certificate (the user certificate) revocation is unknown when determining certificate verification.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreInvalidBasicConstraints
member.summary: Ignore that the basic constraints are not valid when determining certificate verification.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreInvalidName
member.summary: Ignore that the certificate has an invalid name when determining certificate verification.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreInvalidPolicy
member.summary: Ignore that the certificate has invalid policy when determining certificate verification.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreNotTimeNested
member.summary: Ignore that the CA (certificate authority) certificate and the issued certificate have validity periods that are not nested when verifying the certificate. For example, the CA cert can be valid from January 1 to December 1 and the issued certificate from January 2 to December 2, which would mean the validity periods are not nested.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreNotTimeValid
member.summary: Ignore certificates in the chain that are not valid either because they have expired or they are not yet in effect when determining certificate validity.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreRootRevocationUnknown
member.summary: Ignore that the root revocation is unknown when determining certificate verification.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.IgnoreWrongUsage
member.summary: Ignore that the certificate was not issued for the current use when determining certificate verification.

member.name: F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509VerificationFlags.NoFlag
member.summary: No flags pertaining to verification are included.
